image.altText: Birds fly out the front of Parliament House

items.synopsis: For years, debate has raged in the nation's capital about the need for a federal anti-corruption watchdog — one with actual teeth. Now the National Anti-Corruption Commission is here, so what will it achieve?

title.children: The army major general turned federal anti-corruption boss officially starts today — what's ahead of him?

image.altText: Fireworks light up the sky and silhouettes of people watching

items.synopsis: This year 228 tonnes of fireworks have been imported and people will detonate them with few rules and regulations — long after cracker nights were banned in every other state and territory.

title.children: Why people in the NT hold tight the right to blow things up for one wild night each year

image.altText: A silhouette of a person standing near a fire on a street in Paris at night

items.synopsis: French police clear protesters from the iconic central Paris square of Place de la Concorde after an impromptu demonstration started amid nationwide unrest following the fatal shooting of a teenager by police.

title.children: France holds crisis meetings, Macron blames riots on people 'intoxicated' by video games

image.altText: a young man wearing a brimmed hat on a bench holding whips

items.synopsis: In a small Northern Territory town where the outback meets the tropics, Nathan Griggs is cracking his whips in time to Australian rock anthems.

title.children: Record-holding whip cracker shows NT tourists a cracking good time

image.altText: Vladimir Putin's face is lit by warm sunlight. He wears dark sunglasses and a black jacket on black shirt

items.synopsis: As the war grinds on and the traitor Yevgeny Prigozhin is allowed to live on in exile, the question must be asked: Is Vladimir Putin losing his grip on power?

title.children: Russia's elites have a plan in case Putin is toppled. Here's how it could happen

image.altText: The window of an Apple store with a large Apple logo on it

items.synopsis: The company, co-founded by Steve Jobs had briefly eclipsed a $US3 trillion market value on back-to-back days in January 2022, but couldn't hold on by the time the market closed.

title.children: Apple becomes first public company to close at $US3 trillion market value

image.altText: A woman in a red hat leaning on a rusty bar of a gate.

items.synopsis: Australia's richest woman was in London this week celebrating the arrival of tariff-free beef from her cattle enterprises, as the UK free trade deal kicks into gear.

title.children: Gina Rinehart stakes a claim in UK beef market, as new free trade agreement begins

image.altText: Commander James O'Brien pictured outside the court

items.synopsis: The coroner heard the officer had been relieved of his acting assistant commissioner duties after giving an "unfortunate interview" on ABC Radio, where he was questioned about the NT police force's response to domestic violence call-outs.

title.children: Senior NT cop 'no longer fulfilling' acting assistant commissioner role after 'unfortunate interview', DV inquest hears

image.altText: Stack of gold coins on a pink background

items.synopsis: With the start of the new financial year bringing no relief to unrelenting cost-of-living pressures, experts recommend you review your finances and set new budgets and goals.

title.children: The new financial year's begun — here's how to do a money reset and get a hold of your finances

image.altText: A woman dressed in purple holding flowers supported by friends and family in purple

items.synopsis: After two decades of silence, Craig Rumsby confesses to the murder of Gulgong teenager Michelle Bright in 1999 and is found guilty.

title.children: 'I've waited 24 years for this': Michelle Bright's mother in tears as Dubbo court convicts killer

image.altText: A man and woman look out a window, the woman is on her phone

items.synopsis: Darwin residents Denis and Jen Kuhl attempted to call police multiple times when they saw a neighbour and her toddler in distress.

title.children: ‘She'll be safe in the park’: Residents concerned by apparent police response to domestic violence call-out

image.altText: An official looks monitoring activities of earthquake at an observation post mount Merapi in Yogyakarta, Indonesia.

items.synopsis: The magnitude-6.4 earthquake shakes residents of the densely populated Indonesian region, killing one in the ensuing panic.

title.children: Earthquake shakes Java, leaving one dead and dozens of buildings damaged

image.altText: Passengers queing at airport

items.synopsis: Passengers at Sydney Airport have been hit with a second day of flight cancellations and delays due to gusty winds.

title.children: More than 30 flights cancelled at Sydney Airport on first day of school holidays

image.altText: Exterior of a house in suburban Alice Springs.

items.synopsis: Following the manslaughter of Kwementyaye McCormack, a Supreme Court judge has described domestic violence as "a scourge on our society" that causes "deep and lasting trauma".

title.children: Ten years' jail for NT man who fatally stabbed partner in 'senseless and tragic death'

image.altText: Boxer Tim Tszyu smiles at the camera, with fists clenched and a world title belt slun over his shoulder.

items.synopsis: The slated fight between Tim Tszyu and Jermell Charlo is officially called off as the American decides to battle Canelo Alvarez instead.

title.children: Tszyu and Charlo fight officially called off, with Australian set to be named full world champion

image.altText: A man holds his arm in pain while lying on the ground.

items.synopsis: England officials say Ollie Pope was forced back onto the field by the umpires before he re-injured his shoulder.

title.children: 'Bewildered by it all': England officials frustrated after injured Pope is sent back out to field

image.altText: A man standing with an antique Ford tractor.

items.synopsis: Ron Dehne's interest in the Ford began when he was a teenager working his first job at a regional Victorian dealership. This weekend he plans to open his collection to the public.

title.children: Ron's first Ford tractor got bogged so he bought his second to pull it out. Now there are 120 in the shed

image.altText: A young woman with brown hair smiles at the camera

items.synopsis: A move to use a partner from a private PR firm to backfill as the media advisor for the Tasmanian premier is labelled "wrong" and "inappropriate" and should be "terminated forthwith", critics say.

title.children: 'Obviously wrong': PR firm partner to fill in as premier's media advisor

image.altText: The logo of South Austraia's Independent Commission Against Corruption.

items.synopsis: Transcripts of bugged private conversations, tabled in parliament as part of a review report, have revealed a former top South Australian bureaucrat told his colleague she should "never admit to a thing" during a conversation about the details of a taxpayer-funded trip to Melbourne.

title.children: Secret recordings of former Renewal SA boss revealed in ICAC review

image.altText: Girl looking straight at camera with spinifex bush in background.

items.synopsis: Kira Gusterson heard rumours of a "Pilbara tax" before she moved to the iron ore mining region — but she was still shocked by the cost of living.

title.children: Living in a mining town when you're not on a mining wage

image.altText: Jim Chalmers sitting in the House of Representatives. He holds his hand over his mouth.

items.synopsis: The cost-of-living crisis cannot be resolved by one institution alone and raising interest rates isn't the only way to take money out of the economy, writes David Taylor.

title.children: Interest rates needn't be as high as they are, but the government would need to act, top economist says

image.altText: Ishan Jayasekara, Lasitha Bandara and Supun Pollgolla stand together, looking serious.

items.synopsis: Four men badly burned when a gas bottle exploded in Canberra nearly five years ago say they are still suffering from the pain and trauma.

title.children: 'It felt like hell': Four men burned in Canberra gas explosion say they remain physically and mentally scarred

image.altText: Stuart Broad shrugs while holding a ball during an Ashes Test against Australia.

items.synopsis: England's ultra-attacking batting costs them dearly once again, with near misses during Australia's second innings twisting the knife into Stuart Broad in particular.

title.children: Five quick hits — Stuart Broad gets in a strop after England's batters fall in a heap again

image.altText: Pat Cummins lies on his back while completing a catch, Josh Hazlewood pumps his fist and Jonny Bairstow watches on

items.synopsis: With the match in the balance on the third morning, an incredible display of irresponsible English batting gifted Australia the ascendancy and again raised questions about the validity of the host's tactical approach.

title.children: England's absurd batting gifts Australia Ashes advantage and puts Bazball in the firing line

image.altText: A large crowd of people with signs saying 'Justice pour Nahel' are pictured walking in a march, a white van drives through it.

items.synopsis: France entered its third night of riots after police shot dead a 17-year-old in his car. What is happening and why is it escalating?

title.children: Clashes with police, burning cars and widespread demonstrations — What is happening in France?

image.altText: Allan Border smiles while wearing a tuxedo at an awards ceremony

items.synopsis: Australian cricket great Allan Border tells News Corp it will be "a miracle" if he makes it to 80 after living with Parkinson's for years.

title.children: Allan Border reveals he has Parkinson's disease

image.altText: a cloud band forms over the kimberley

items.synopsis: Unseasonable rain continues to fall across Australia's north in what's meant to be the region's dry season, helping lower temperatures to near-record levels.

title.children: Why holiday-makers heading north for winter sun could be in for unpleasant surprise

image.altText: A woman resting her chin on her hand smiles at the camera.

items.synopsis: Millions of Australians are opting for career changes, but experts say the window may be closing to get the most out of the "Great Reshuffle". This is how mid-career professionals jumped at the chance for an occupation transformation and set themselves up for a more fulfilling work future.

title.children: Would you take a $50,000 pay cut? Why these mid-career professionals aren't looking back

image.altText: Two women in 1800s period-costume dresses walk past timber huts.

items.synopsis: Jack Yabsley, a former presenter of Saturday Disney and Totally Wild, describes his new TV series Gold Diggers as an anti-patriarchal, "grubby, political, silly, sexy comedy".

title.children: Former kids' TV presenter creates bawdy comedy about women on Australia's goldfields

image.altText: Narendra Modi gestures with arms wide and palms up as he speaks into two mics at a lectern.

items.synopsis: As the next federal elections loom in India, Prime Minister Narendra Modi is pushing for a single legal code to cover matters currently governed by different sets of laws for different religious groups.

title.children: Narendra Modi wants to do away with customised laws based on religion, caste or creed

image.altText: Two men in bright yellow hazmat suits attend to a large yellow firefighting hose in a car park.

items.synopsis: The accusation came after Kyiv accused Russia earlier in June of planning a "terrorist" attack at the nuclear plant involving the release of radiation, which Moscow has denied.

title.children: Russians reducing personnel at Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, Ukrainian intelligence says

mediaThumbnail.caption: WA surfer Ned Hart went viral when footage of the 16-year-old riding a spectacularly large and dangerous wave in Tasmania was posted online seconds after the ride ended. For a kid chasing the surfing dream in the digital age, the coverage could prove more valuable than a brace of sponsors ever could.

children.content: Supplied: Tim Bonython and ABC South West WA: Anthony Pancia

byLine.plain: Supplied: Tim Bonython and ABC South West WA: Anthony Pancia

document.caption: WA surfer Ned Hart went viral when footage of the 16-year-old riding a spectacularly large and dangerous wave in Tasmania was posted online seconds after the ride ended. For a kid chasing the surfing dream in the digital age, the coverage proved more valuable than a brace of sponsors ever could.
document.synopsis: WA surfer Ned Hart went viral when footage of the 16-year-old riding a spectacularly large and dangerous wave in Tasmania was posted online seconds after the ride ended. For a kid chasing the surfing dream in the digital age, the coverage proved more valuable than a brace of sponsors ever could.

synopsisAlt.lg: WA surfer Ned Hart went viral when footage of the 16-year-old riding a spectacularly large and dangerous wave in Tasmania was posted online seconds after the ride ended. For a kid chasing the surfing dream in the digital age, the coverage proved more valuable than a brace of sponsors ever could.

For a kid chasing the surfing dream in the digital age, the coverage proved more valuable than a brace of sponsors ever could.

document.title: Ned Hart nets dream wave in Tasmania

titleAlt.lg: Ned Hart nets dream wave in Tasmania
titleAlt.md: Ned Hart nets dream wave in Tasmania
titleAlt.sm: Ned Hart nets dream wave in Tasmania

items.synopsis: Ned Hart hits it big with a wild ride in Tasmania and the coverage is proving to be worth more than any contest win.

title.children: 16yo WA surfer sets internet ablaze with wild ride in Tasmania
